formatted_items.content:
Subject: Cover Design Briefs and Reference Materials for Upcoming Titles

Hi Mary,

Thank you for partnering with Literary Horizons on our next round of releases! Below you’ll find the key information you’ll need to begin developing the cover concepts, along with links to more detailed reference files.

––––––––––––––––––––
PROJECT 1
Working Title: “Whispers of the Forgotten Isles”  
Author: Lena Durant (represented by Creative Minds Author Agency)  
Genre & Tone: Epic fantasy; atmospheric, adventurous, slightly dark  
Target Readers: Adults 18–40 who enjoy Brandon Sanderson-style world-building  
Core Visual Ideas:  
• A mist-shrouded archipelago at dawn  
• Stylized compass rose worked into the typography  
• Jewel-toned color palette—sapphire, teal, and touches of gold  
Deliverables Requested:  
• Front cover, full wrap, and title treatment as a standalone asset

PROJECT 2
Working Title: “The Quantum Heart”  
Author: Dr. Caleb Monroe  
Genre & Tone: Near-future sci-fi romance; sleek, hopeful, high-tech  
Target Readers: NA & adult romance readers with a tech/science bend  
Core Visual Ideas:  
• Subtle circuitry pattern forming the silhouette of a heart  
• Soft neon glows (electric blue & magenta) on a charcoal background  
• Clean sans-serif typography, slightly condensed  
Deliverables Requested:  
• Front cover only (ebook first), plus alternate colorway for print

PROJECT 3
Working Title: “The Orchard Keeper’s Handbook”  
Author: Martha Ellison  
Genre & Tone: Illustrated nonfiction; warm, instructional, down-to-earth  
Target Readers: Hobby gardeners & small-scale farmers  
Core Visual Ideas:  
• Hand-drawn botanical illustration wraparound  
• Earthy palette: sage greens, soft creams, muted terracotta  
• Serif title font paired with handwritten subtitle  
Deliverables Requested:  
• Full wrap cover, 8–10 chapter opener spot illos, and style guide

––––––––––––––––––––
Reference Material & Assets

1. Gmail Thread  
   I’ve forwarded you a thread titled “Cover Inspirations & Market Comparisons.” It contains comps the authors love, sales data, and mood-board imagery. If you don’t see it, please let me know and I’ll resend.

2. The Editor’s Companion Workspace  
   • Book Specs: Trim sizes, spine widths, paper types  
   • Author Questionnaires: Additional notes on themes, must-have elements, and hard avoids  
   • Production Timeline: Key internal milestones and final print deadlines  

(Quick access link: https://editors-companion.com/lh-covers [login with your usual credentials])

––––––––––––––––––––
Timeline & Next Steps

• First concept presentation: Friday, 14 June  
• Internal feedback returned: Wednesday, 19 June  
• Second round revisions: Due Tuesday, 25 June  
• Final files to production: Thursday, 4 July

If any of these dates are tight, just let me know––we can adjust as needed.

––––––––––––––––––––
Questions?

Please feel free to reach out if anything here is unclear or if you’d like to hop on a quick call to discuss direction. Your creative vision always elevates our projects, and I’m excited to see where you take these covers!

Thanks again, Mary. Looking forward to your concepts.

Best,
John
Senior Editor, Literary Horizons
john.editor@literaryhorizons.com | +1 555-0134
